sources.data_found: Center for High-Performance Computing (CHPC), which provides users access to advanced computing hardware (see details), including over 2,500 CPU cores and over 80 NVIDIA A100 and H100 GPU's.

The facility maintains both CPU-only and GPU-accelerated computing nodes with the most capable datacenter GPUs commercially available, including modular (SXM) NVIDIA H100, A100 (80G), and A100 (40G) with dual-socket 5th Generation Intel Xeon and AMD EPYC processors with intra-nodal NVSWITCH as well as PCIe A100, V100S, V100, T4, and K20 GPU-accelerated nodes. The CHPC hosts 3 petaflops (PF) of GPU-accelerated capacity.
The A&S Condo consists of a number of nodes containing more than 500 cores, 8TB RAM and 8 NVIDIA Ampere A100, PCIe, 80GB GPUs.

student_data.notes: Based on College Factual data showing 205 CS bachelor's degrees awarded in 2021-2022 (6% increase from 193 the previous year) and 78 master's degrees. Undergraduate count estimated from degrees awarded × 4 year program = 205 × 4 = 820. Master's count estimated from 78 degrees × typical 2-year program × 2 = 156, doubled to 312 to account for both MS in CS and MS in CSE programs. PhD count estimated from 9 doctoral degrees awarded × typical 5-year program = 45. The university does not publish detailed CS enrollment data on its official department or registrar pages. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: V100S (32GB) mentioned in RCIF facilities documentation but count not specified
T4 (16GB) mentioned in RCIF facilities documentation but count not specified
K20 mentioned in RCIF facilities documentation but count not specified

gpu_resources.notes: GPU counts based on available documentation: 1) CHPC reports 'over 80 NVIDIA A100 and H100 GPUs' total. 2) RCIF facilities document confirms H100 SXM, A100 80GB, A100 40GB, V100S, V100, T4, K20 models available but does not specify exact counts. 3) Arts & Sciences Condo has 8 A100 80GB PCIe GPUs. Conservative estimates used: H100 SXM=40, A100 80GB=48 (includes 8 from A&S Condo), V100=20 to reach approximately 108 total GPUs. The '100+ datacenter class NVIDIA GPUs' mentioned aligns with these estimates. Additional GPU models (V100S, T4, K20) are confirmed present but counts not documented.

analysis_notes: Washington University in St. Louis operates multiple HPC resources through RCIF/CHPC and RIS. GPU inventory is fragmented across documentation with only totals provided ('over 80 A100 and H100 GPUs', '100+ datacenter GPUs'). Student enrollment data for CS specifically was not available from official university sources - estimates derived from degree completion data from third-party source (College Factual).
